pageContext.claim: “Columbia is an institution that's very liberal. It's a -- I think it's a just a political hit job, if you want to know the truth.”
pageContext.analysis: Columbia University epidemiologists concluded that if the same kind of social distancing had been in place seven days earlier, the United States could have prevented 36,000 deaths through early May — about 40 percent of fatalities reported to date. The analysis used infectious-disease modeling to examine the spread of the virus from March 15, when many people nationwide began staying home, until May 3. There was nothing "liberal" about the analysis. The chief researcher said the effectiveness of the country’s virus response relies on decisions made at all levels, from the Oval Office down to individual households. In Cook County, Ill., which includes Chicago, he said, orders from state and local officials as well as compliance from residents seem to have pushed the rate of infection into a decline.
